paper.title: Phase-curve Evidence for an Atmosphere on TRAPPIST-1 b

core_question: Whether TRAPPIST-1 b retains an atmosphere, using JWST MIRI phase-curve spectroscopy to jointly constrain day-night heat transport and atmospheric composition.

datasets_or_cohorts.label: Observed TRAPPIST-1 b phase-curve spectra
datasets_or_cohorts.sample_size_or_observations: One rocky exoplanet observed with phase-resolved thermal spectra
datasets_or_cohorts.description: Phase-resolved thermal spectra of TRAPPIST-1 b from JWST MIRI low-resolution spectroscopy over an orbital phase curve, including thermal phase variation and structure near the 15 um CO2 band.

datasets_or_cohorts.label: Bare-rock (no-atmosphere) scenario
datasets_or_cohorts.description: A null scenario assuming a bare-rock, no-atmosphere model with minimal heat redistribution, compared against atmosphere-bearing retrieval models.

datasets_or_cohorts.label: CO2-rich atmosphere scenario
datasets_or_cohorts.description: An atmosphere-bearing scenario with significant greenhouse gas absorption, evaluated via retrieval models against the observed phase-curve and spectral structure around the 15 um CO2 band.

datasets_or_cohorts.label: O2-rich atmosphere scenario
datasets_or_cohorts.description: An oxidized (O2-rich) atmosphere scenario considered in retrievals, with weaker CO2 signature constraints and not fully ruled out by the current dataset.

major_limitations: Single-planet study; does not establish prevalence across rocky M-dwarf planets.
Retrieval assumptions (circulation, opacity priors, clouds) affect quantitative posteriors.
Stellar variability and instrument systematics can bias weak spectral features.
Night-side constraints are weaker than day-side constraints in the current dataset.
Degeneracies between composition, clouds/hazes, and circulation remain significant.
